rComments: Easy going class but the lectures feel like they drag on forever, and most people weren't able to stay for the full 3 hours of class because of how dry and boring his classes were. He is extremely monotone, and his tests are nothing like the weekly assignments. Overall tough class, but pretty much free marks for pop quizzes and weekly assignments.
teacherRatingTags: ['Beware of pop quizzes', 'Tough grader', 'Get ready to read']

rComments: Marc is a very knowledgeable guy. I just finished writing his final exam; oh man was it freaking difficult! I had an A+ before I wrote the final (the course was interesting to me) and I think I barely passed the final. His exams are really tough but on the other hand APLIA assignments are free 20% and another 9% just for attendance. TOUGH COURSE!
Excellent knowledge, has traveled a lot and worked with many world class economists.  Wrote many interesting books and articles.

Very good prof ! I've had him a few times - way better in smaller classes then in Intro, but very interesting nonetheless. One of the most knowledgable profs of Economics at U of O, if not Canada. Not the best lecturer (sometimes hard to understand), but his accent did not bother me at all, considering the info he teaches is also in the textbook.
I liked him. Nice guy, and he loves what he studies. Not a great public speaker but has a great mind, give him a chance. He has worked with some of the best economists in the world
Most boring lectures ever! The exams aren't too hard. And the APLIA online quizzes are like a free 100% for 25% of your mark!!! The exams are fair.
His exams were difficult, but if you used the slides as a guide to studying the book, then it was easy(ish). Aplia kicked ass. Free 20% plus attendence, free 5%. He is a slow talker though.

Not the best english, not very exciting or interesting. Aplia will do wonders for you if you actually do it. It worked for me. If you go to class its a quick 5% for attendance. Try to go to all classes. Midterm was tough. Final was very easy if u studied. Textbook driven class.

Random attendance. Not an engaging speaker, but has a sense of humour. I believe he would be a better teacher of higher level ECO courses, but is not the best for an English intro course. Difficult exams. He practically speaks from the textbook.

He was teaching the English section; but his English is horrible which is the first problem.  He is boring, has no authority on the class, and basically only reads off power point slides during class. He was also plugging his textbook which isn't helpful.  Exams were tough, and Aplia was graded on your first try so you can't learn first.
Every time I go to class I struggle to stay awake. Too much information and very hard midterm. Don't recommend.
He was a nightmare. I strongly advice you not to take any course he teaches.

I took this class, switched over to the English, taught by Greg Tkaczh(sp?). Lavoie class was confusing. Greg's class, we learned a huge amount, the English class was so much better, it was also packed with 80+ students...If you study very hard=A+ in the English class, with Lavoie A+ is a hit or miss.

Overall not bad.  The beginning of the course sucked, very confusing, but got better halfway through.  The exams are based completely on class notes.  Very tough midterm, but graded generously.  Still kinda wish I took it in english because I hear the students in the english class learned more.

Although his class tends to be boring,but sometimes I like to hear his strange comments about the text and mainstream economics.It is the course content I don't like.It covers about 20 chapters,14 chapters to study for the final exam!Too much stuffs made the course hard to digest and a nightmare
Hard to understand class, he made no sense, switch to English Macro3 (3152), it made all the sense in the world.  Post Keynesian bull.
Very good.

Take this course if you want to permanently mess up your understanding of economics. NOBODY else in the world (even marxists) takes his Post-Keysian economics seriously. He makes you buy his own crap textbook (no wonder! everything he teaches he makes up)

Very interesting and critical of the mainstream, but still teaches all perspectives well. Does tonnes of research in post-keynesian economics. Fair exams, mostly based on material presented in class. Readings are somewhat useful.
No Comments
